author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Gabby Sobelman
title: The World’s Last Samaritans, Straddling the Israeli-Palestinian Divide
description: Up a mountain in the West Bank, several hundred villagers practice an ancient Israelite religion while maintaining an ambiguous national identity.
content: MOUNT GERIZIM, West Bank — In the occupied and largely segregated West Bank, Jews live in gated Israeli settlements and Palestinians live in Arab cities and towns. And then there are the 440 residents of the mountaintop village of Al Tor, who float between both worlds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristin Hussey
title: Coastal towns in Connecticut are recommending evacuations.
description: Power companies said downed trees might leave hundreds of thousands of customers without electricity for as long as three weeks.
content: STAMFORD, Conn. — The National Hurricane Center warned on Saturday that shoreline towns in Connecticut might be inundated by storm surge from Hurricane Henri, possibly causing major flooding south of Route 1, a major artery through the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: U.S. steps up efforts to evacuate Afghans.
content: The Pentagon ordered six commercial airlines to provide passenger jets to help with the growing U.S. military operation evacuating Americans and Afghan allies fleeing the Taliban takeover in Kabul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Do you have a medical bill we should investigate? Share it with us.
description: Readers’ bills can help us understand the high costs of our health care system.
content: The New York Times is looking into the high costs of American health care and the wide price variation that patients face from one hospital or doctor’s office to another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Michaela Coel Puts Herself Together in ‘Misfits’
description: The book, adapted from a speech by the creator and star of “I May Destroy You,” codifies her efforts to achieve transparency in her work and in her life.
content: The city of Edinburgh was the epicenter of a powerful energy pulse on Aug. 22, 2018 — not the kind that precise scientific equipment can detect, but one whose ripples would be felt by sensitive human instruments in the weeks and months that followed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Matt Stevens
title: Biden says the Afghan evacuation deadline may be extended.
description: The president defended the U.S. efforts in Kabul and said the military had evacuated “an extraordinary number of people” since July.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Sunday that his administration might extend his Aug. 31 deadline for removing all American troops from Afghanistan, and he pledged that all evacuated Afghan allies will be given a home in the United States after they are screened and vetted at bases in other countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Hung Liu, Artist Who Blended East and West, Is Dead at 73
description: An immigrant from China, she once said her goal was “to invent a way of allowing myself to practice as a Chinese artist outside of a Chinese culture.”
content: Hung Liu, a Chinese American artist whose work merged past and present, East and West, earning her acclaim in her adopted country and censorship in the land of her birth, died on Aug. 7 at her home in Oakland, Calif. She was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Good, but Not Great: Taking Stock of a Big Ten University’s Covid Plan
description: The University of Illinois says an aggressive testing program prevented deaths on and off campus during the last academic year. Now the university is contending with the Delta variant.
content: This week is the start of a new academic year at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Steel
title: Rachel Maddow, MSNBC’s Top Host, Extends Her Contract
description: Ms. Maddow was reported to have expressed interest in leaving the network to pursue podcasting and streaming projects.
content: Rachel Maddow, the top-rated anchor at MSNBC, has renewed her contract with the cable news network, extending her 13-year run for several more years, according to a person briefed on the deal who was not authorized to speak on it publicly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: In Haiti, Need Is Overwhelming, but Some Politicians’ Charity Rings False
description: Potential candidates’ donations to quake victims have taken on political overtones and highlighted the government’s failures in providing relief.
content: LES CAYES, Haiti — Hundreds of Haitian earthquake victims desperately lined up for hot meals delivered to a sweltering makeshift camp this past week, fighting over — and scooping from the muddy ground — rice and chicken that spilled from plastic food containers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: After Loss, Manny Pacquiao Is Left to Consider His Future
description: Pacquiao did not announce his retirement after a defeat to Yordenis Ugas in Saturday’s title bout. But he dropped some hints and has also publicly considered a run for president of the Philippines.
content: An hour after defeating Manny Pacquiao in their welterweight title fight, Yordenis Ugas strode into his news conference sporting a glittering watch and a matching, two-stranded necklace, a pair of shades and the wide smile of a man who knew he had just ascended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Chaos Persists at Kabul Airport as Taliban Discuss New Government
description: The militants have engaged the former officials Hamid Karzai and Abdullah Abdullah, as well as Moscow, to seek help in building an “inclusive” government while cementing their rule.
content: As lethal mayhem persisted outside Kabul airport, with thousands of terrified Afghans trying to flee, the Taliban have reached out to a former Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, and to Russia in an attempt to fulfill their pledge to form an “inclusive” government and defeat holdouts against their rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Here’s why you need bottled water during a hurricane or tropical storm.
description: Powerful storms such as Tropical Storm Henri can cause power outages or damage public water systems.
content: Having an ample supply of clean water is a top priority during extreme weather systems such as Tropical Storm Henri.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jesse Jackson and his wife, Jacqueline, are hospitalized with Covid-19.
description: Mr. Jackson, 79, was vaccinated in January.
content: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and his wife, Jacqueline, have been hospitalized after testing positive for Covid-19, Mr. Jackson’s Rainbow PUSH Coalition said on Saturday in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Molly Seidel Is Not Going to ‘Phone It In’ for the New York City Marathon
description: The race will be Seidel’s most conventional 26.2 mile race thus far. But this is not a fun run.
content: Molly Seidel has run a lot of loops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: God, Money, YOLO: How Cathie Wood Found Her Flock
description: Ms. Wood says the Holy Spirit moved her to strike out on her own after an up-and-down career in money management. But it’s her belief in herself that won the Reddit crowd’s faith.
content: Cathie Wood was in familiar territory. She was listening to someone tell her she was wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: At Least 22 Dead and 50 Missing in Tennessee Floods, Officials Say
description: Among those killed were several children, including twin 7-month-olds, officials said. Given the number of fatalities, they expected there would be more recovery efforts than rescue efforts.
content: At least 22 people were killed and 50 others remained missing on Sunday after catastrophic flash floods swept through Middle Tennessee, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: With 500th Homer, Cabrera Joins a Club That’s Getting More Exclusive
description: Miguel Cabrera is the 28th player to join the 500-homer club. Despite a surge of new members in recent years, there may be a long wait for a 29th.
content: They don’t make them like Miguel Cabrera anymore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cybèle C. Greenberg
title: Could Cyberwar Make the World Safer?
description: Hacking, like war, is the continuation of politics by other means, but without the inevitable sacrifice of lives.
content: The battles in a global cyberwar are visible only through periodic glances in the rearview mirror: Indra, Colonial Pipeline, SolarWinds, WannaCry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I’m Just So Tired of My Body Failing Me in Different Ways’
description: Overhearing some unusual health advice, a very good first date and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Sardinian Village Tries to Save an Ancient Tree Scorched by Fire
description: A team of experts, with the help of local residents and authorities, is trying to revive an ancient olive tree in the hilltop village of Cuglieri that was engulfed in a catastrophic wildfire.
content: To the people of Cuglieri, a small hilltop village on the Italian island of Sardinia, the tree was simply “the Patriarch.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Lucille Times, Who Inspired the Montgomery Bus Boycott, Dies at 100
description: Six months before Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat, Mrs. Times had an altercation with a bus driver and stopped riding the city’s segregated buses.
content: Lucille Times, whose encounter with a bus driver in Montgomery, Ala., in June 1955 led her to begin a one-woman boycott of the city’s public transportation, an act of defiance that inspired a mass boycott six months later after another Black woman, Rosa Parks, was charged with defying the same bus driver, died on Aug. 16 at the home of her nephew Daniel Nichols. She was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: ‘My Blood Is Boiling’: War Fever Surges in Ethiopia as Its Civil War Spreads
description: A government drive to enlist civilians in the war effort threatens to widen the conflict, forcing ethnic groups to take sides and potentially spilling into the broader region.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — He swept to power preaching unity and hope, struck a landmark peace deal with the longtime foe Eritrea, released thousands of political prisoners, lifted restrictions on the press and promised to overturn decades of repressive authoritarian rule. For those accomplishments, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Tony Blair, who led the U.K. into Afghanistan, criticizes the pullout.
description: The former prime minister of Britain called the withdrawal ‘an imbecilic political slogan about ending ‘the forever wars.’
content: Tony Blair, the former prime minister of Britain, on Saturday criticized the withdrawal from Afghanistan, calling it a hasty move made “in obedience to an imbecilic political slogan about ending ‘the forever wars.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Traci Carl
title: Phil Valentine, a radio host who scoffed at Covid, then urged his followers to get vaccinated, dies.
description: Mr. Valentine’s hospitalization for Covid-19 made him an advocate for vaccines.
content: Phil Valentine, a prominent conservative radio host in Tennessee who refused to get vaccinated, then urged his followers to get a shot after being hospitalized with Covid-19, has died, his station said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: ISIS Poses ‘Acute’ Threat to U.S. Evacuation Efforts in Kabul, Sullivan Says
description: President Biden’s national security adviser warned of mounting but unspecified terrorist risks to the U.S. mission to evacuate thousands of Americans and Afghan allies.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s national security adviser warned on Sunday that the threat of a terrorist attack by the Islamic State posed a serious danger to the administration’s evacuation of thousands of Americans and Afghan allies from the international airport in Kabul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: How many Americans are waiting to leave Afghanistan? The U.S. isn’t sure.
description: U.S. officials estimated last week that as many as 15,000 Americans were in Afghanistan. President Biden’s national security adviser said on Sunday that he didn’t have a precise number.
content: At the center of the scramble to airlift American citizens out of Afghanistan after its fall to the Taliban is a basic question: How many Americans are waiting to be evacuated?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kiana Hayeri
title: What Will Become of Afghanistan’s Post-9/11 Generation?
description: This summer, the journalist Kiana Hayeri set out to photograph Afghans who grew up after the U.S. invasion in 2001. Instead, she wound up documenting the end of life as they knew it.
content: Gul Ahmad went to school only until fifth grade. After his father died, his mother remarried. When Gul Ahmad was 12, his stepfather forced him to go to Iran to work and bring money back to the family. At the time of the photo above, the boys had traveled to Iran, hoping to find work, but were deported back to Afghanistan and waiting at a center for migrants to be reunited with their families. When Hayeri met them, they were constantly on their phones. Gul Ahmad played games, and Karim watched videos of young Iranian women smoking hookah and playing guitar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Michael Levenson
title: A Tidal Wave of Water and at Least 22 Deaths as Floodwaters Ravage Rural Tennessee
description: An area of rivers, creeks and rolling woods had seen flooding before but nothing approximating the torrent of water that overwhelmed rural communities on Saturday.
content: WAVERLY, Tenn. — In one moment, Rickey Larkin saw the creek running behind his home spill over its banks. The next, he said, he was engulfed by an ocean. His pickup was carried away by the currents. Then, the water came surging into his home and rose shoulder high, forcing him, his wife and their cat to cling to a mattress as a life raft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry and Will Sennott
title: As Henri approached, memories of Hurricane Bob came rushing back.
description: Hurricane Bob, which caused the deaths of more than a dozen people and hundreds of millions of dollars in damage in 1991, remains the last hurricane to make landfall in New England.
content: Thirty years ago this week, M.L. Baron stocked his van with provisions — deviled ham and two 30-packs of Coors Light — fired up his shoe-box-size cellphone, parked beside the New Bedford, Mass., waterfront and waited for Hurricane Bob.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Chocolate Chip Cities
description: Black presence and Black power in America are on a seesaw.
content: The term “inner city” has long been used as a derisive euphemism for Black — poor, blighted and in distress. But many inner cities in the North and West are becoming less and less Black because Black people are moving out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Don Everly, Older Brother in Groundbreaking Rock Duo, Dies at 84
description: The Everly Brothers, Don and Phil, were the most successful rock act to emerge from Nashville in the 1950s, rivaling Elvis Presley for radio airplay.
content: NASHVILLE — Don Everly, the elder of the two Everly Brothers, the groundbreaking duo whose fusion of Appalachian harmonies and a tighter, cleaner version of big-beat rock ’n’ roll made them harbingers of both folk-rock and country-rock, died on Saturday at his home here. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Deeply Divided, House Democrats Battle Over Priorities and Politics
description: The House returns to Washington on Monday to try to win passage of a measure needed to protect a $3.5 trillion social policy bill from a filibuster, but fractures in the party are starting to show.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats will end their summer break on Monday, amid finger-pointing and rising tensions, to try to pave the legislative way for the most ambitious expansion of the nation’s social safety net in a half century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Whiteside
title: At 25, Liberty Celebrate ‘Magical Moment’ in Women’s Basketball
description: Early Liberty teams regularly contended for the W.N.B.A. championship and built an enduring connection with fans.
content: Margaret Martinez did her best, but she knew she needed to work on her game. Her 8-year-old daughter, Mackenzie, had fallen in love with the Liberty rookie Didi Richards’ defense and her hairstyle — two peppy Afro puffs. When Martinez couldn’t get Mackenzie’s puffs quite right, she reached out to Richards on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassady Rosenblum
title: Work Is a False Idol
description: From Diogenes the Cynic to Audre Lorde to a former factory worker in China, the “lying flat” movement is gathering steam.
content: In China this April, a 31-year-old former factory worker named Luo Huazhong drew the curtains and crawled into bed. Then he posted a picture of himself there to the Chinese website Baidu along with a message: “Lying Flat Is Justice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde Haberman
title: As Afghanistan Collapses, a Lament for ‘Repeating the Same Mistakes’
description: Shifting objectives led to the expansion of a war that dragged on for almost two decades, and is ending in chaos.
content: Few people in Congress have stood as alone as Representative Barbara Lee did on Sept. 14, 2001. Three days earlier, the United States had endured the most devastating attack ever on its soil. Now Congress was called on to authorize the unleashing of American military power against Al Qaeda and its Taliban enablers in Afghanistan who were held responsible for what has eternally come to be called 9/11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: ‘No One Quite Knows What to Say’: A War Easily Ignored Ends With Few Answers
description: At any Army base in Colorado, little acknowledgment as the war in Afghanistan comes to an abrupt and chaotic end.
content: FORT CARSON, Colo. — At the main gate of this busy Army post is a sandstone slab etched with the names of Fort Carson soldiers killed in Afghanistan and Iraq.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas says he tests negative for coronavirus.
description: Mr. Abbott encouraged others to get vaccinated, crediting his inoculation with preventing serious illness from Covid.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas announced on Saturday that he had tested negative for the coronavirus, four days after testing positive. He said he will continue to quarantine at the recommendation of doctors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Josephine Baker to Be Honored With a Panthéon Burial
description: Ms. Baker will be the first Black woman to be entombed in the Panthéon in Paris, a symbolic move amid racial tensions in France.
content: PARIS — Josephine Baker, an American-born Black dancer and civil rights activist who in the early 20th century became one of France’s great music-hall stars, will be laid to rest in the Panthéon, France’s storied tomb of heroes, a close adviser to President Emmanuel Macron said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Why We Need to Start Talking About God
description: Who are we? What are we here for?
content: This is a preview of the Tish Harrison Warren newsletter, which is reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox weekly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: There! I Did It!
description: Bruce Haight really loves television.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Bruce Haight on his 56th New York Times Crossword puzzle, which is his 17th Monday puzzle!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Schweber
title: Central Park sets a rainfall record.
description: Nearly two inches fell in an hour on Saturday night, the most ever recorded. It was also the rainiest Aug. 21 on record in New York City, with nearly 4.5 inches.
content: In the dark hours as Henri churned in the Atlantic below Eastern Long Island and New England, New York City was deluged by historic rainfall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Afghanistan, Hurricane Henri, Hypebeast Cars: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: A Hospital Finds an Unlikely Group Opposing Vaccination: Its Workers
description: When a Staten Island hospital implemented a vaccine or testing mandate, some of its staff staged angry protests.
content: Their movement started discreetly, just a handful of people communicating on encrypted apps like WhatsApp and Signal. But in just days it had ballooned tenfold. And within two weeks, it had turned into a full-blown public protest, with people waving picket signs to denounce efforts to push them to receive coronavirus vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: How to Look Up Prices at Your Hospital, if They Exist
description: Start with a web search. Consider a third-party tool. Expect frustration.
content: This year, some Americans can do something that was previously impossible: look up the price of care before going to the hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Reid J. Epstein and Annie Karni
title: As Biden Faces a Political Crisis, His Party Looks On in Alarm
description: Democrats fear that if the pandemic or the situation in Afghanistan continues to worsen, their party may lose the confidence of the moderate swing voters who lifted it to victory in 2020.
content: With President Biden facing a political crisis that has shaken his standing in his party, Democrats across the country are increasingly worried about their ability to maintain power in Washington, as his administration struggles to defend its chaotic withdrawal from Afghanistan and stanch a resurgent pandemic that appeared to be waning only weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Case of the Vanishing Jungle’
description: It seemed like an easy crime to stop: protected Indonesian rainforest, cut for coffee farms. But a globalized economy can undermine even the best-laid plans.
content: In 2002, a survey revealed there were just 1.6 Sumatran tigers per 100 square kilometers in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park, one of the last habitats for the critically endangered animal. In the fall of 2015, however, research suggested that the numbers had significantly improved: 2.8 tigers per 100 square kilometers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: ‘Pass Over’ Comes to Broadway, in Horror and Hope
description: Antoinette Chinonye Nwandu’s play about young Black men in peril inaugurates the new season with unexpected joy.
content: On Wednesday night, when a preshow announcement informed the 1,200 or so people at the August Wilson Theater that they were “one of the first audiences back to see a real Broadway play,” the response was the kind of roar you’d expect for a beloved diva returning from rehab. And “Pass Over,” by Antoinette Chinonye Nwandu, does not disappoint in that regard. Having survived pandemic jitters (so far) and its own circuitous path to get there, it emerged like a star: in top shape, at full throttle and refreshed by some artful doctoring.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: America’s Afghan War: Drawing Down an Unwinnable Conflict
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 22, 2021.
content: “If you have to go in, go in with the understanding that you can’t wholly succeed. Don’t go in thinking, you’re going to solve it, or fix it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A Rush of News, Moment by Moment: Behind Our Live Coverage
description: When readers need information immediately, teams of journalists collaborate to tell a single unfolding story.
content: When the Taliban’s takeover of Afghanistan began accelerating with stunning speed, The New York Times quickly shifted into live coverage mode: Reporters and editors posted developments as they happened on the collapse of Kandahar, the disintegration of the Afghan military, the global response to the U.S. government’s actions and more, all packaged together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 4 Dead and 4 Missing in North Carolina Flooding
description: The remnants of Tropical Storm Fred dropped more than 10 inches of rain on Tuesday in Haywood County, N.C., causing the Pigeon River to overflow.
content: Four people were killed and four others were still missing after flash floods wiped out homes in western North Carolina in the wake of Tropical Depression Fred last week, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: The U.S. orders six commercial airlines to help transport Afghan evacuees.
description: The 18 passenger jets won’t fly into or out of Kabul but will help carry people fearing reprisals from Taliban fighters from bases in the Middle East to stops in Europe.
content: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has ordered six commercial airlines to provide passenger jets to help with the growing U.S. military operation evacuating Americans and Afghan allies from Kabul, the Afghan capital, the Pentagon said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Turning Up the Heat on Tesla
description: Tesla is facing the broadest investigation yet into its assisted-driving technology, which it calls Autopilot.
content: The country’s top auto-safety agency announced the broadest investigation yet into Tesla’s assisted-driving technology, which it calls Autopilot, prompted by at least 11 accidents in which Teslas crashed into parked emergency vehicles. The agency is investigating more than two dozen crashes that occurred with Autopilot in use, which resulted in at least 10 deaths. Despite its name, the feature does not make Teslas autonomous. Safety experts say it may encourage distracted driving by giving a false impression about its capabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Ellen Barry
title: Tropical Storm Henri Brings Power Outages and Record Rain to Northeast
description: The storm was expected to continue dumping rain across the region through Monday night, prompting flood watches in several states.
content: Tropical Storm Henri battered the Northeast with fierce winds and torrential rain on Sunday, knocking out power in most of coastal Rhode Island, forcing evacuations in Connecticut, stranding dozens of motorists in New Jersey and shattering rainfall records in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: 16 Cats, 320 Square Feet and One Long-Shot Candidate for Mayor
description: Curtis Sliwa, the founder of the Guardian Angels, wants New Yorkers to take him seriously as a mayoral candidate against Eric Adams.
content: Curtis Sliwa is certainly no novice in the art of grabbing headlines in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: A microscopic video shows the coronavirus on the rampage.
description: Inside a bat’s brain, the pathogen destroys cells, but not before it forces them to build more invaders.
content: The intruder stalks its prey with stealth and precision, preparing to puncture its quarry’s armor. Once inside, the aggressor forces its host to produce more intruders, and then causes it to explode, spewing out a multitude of invaders who can continue their rampage on a wider scale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff, Josh Katz and Rumsey Taylor
title: Hospitals and Insurers Didn’t Want You to See These Prices. Here’s Why.
description: Getting simple medical care at some hospitals can cost more with insurance than without.
content: Getting simple medical care at some hospitals can cost more with insurance than without.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Retro Report
title: How the U.S. military response to the 9/11 attacks led to decades of war.
description: Officials who drove the decades-long war in Afghanistan look back on the strategic mistakes and misjudgments that led to a 20-year quagmire.
content: Officials who drove the decades-long war in Afghanistan look back on the strategic mistakes and misjudgments that led to a 20-year quagmire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Details U.S. Evacuation Efforts in Afghanistan
description: President Biden said that the United States had evacuated an “extraordinary number of people” from Kabul, but that his Aug. 31 deadline for removing all American troops from Afghanistan might be extended.
content: President Biden said that the United States had evacuated an “extraordinary number of people” from Kabul, but that his Aug. 31 deadline for removing all American troops from Afghanistan might be extended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Henri Hits Northeast as a Tropical Storm
description: Tropical Storm Henri made landfall in southwestern Rhode Island on Sunday afternoon. Heavy rainfall ahead of the storm’s landing caused street flooding in New York and New Jersey.
content: Tropical Storm Henri made landfall in southwestern Rhode Island on Sunday afternoon. Heavy rainfall ahead of the storm’s landing caused street flooding in New York and New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Floods in Tennessee Leave More Than a Dozen Dead
description: The authorities were searching house to house after flooding knocked out cellphone service and swamped roads. Among those killed were several children, including twin 7-month-olds.
content: The authorities were searching house to house after flooding knocked out cellphone service and swamped roads. Among those killed were several children, including twin 7-month-olds.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How the Pandemic Is Changing Restaurants
description: Readers discuss rising prices, customer abuse of employees and unionization. Also: The opioid crisis; summer's pleasures.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 22, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 22, 2021.
content: An article on Page 4 this weekend about the project Theater in Quarantine by Joshua William Gelb, using information provided by a publicist, misstates the composer Heather Christian’s age. She is 39, not 29.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Start with a comforting Sunday supper from Madhur Jaffrey, followed by dessert from Nigella Lawson.
content: The other day I sent an email to a colleague asking if she had heard anything on that promotion she was up for. “Not expecting any news soon, since the whole world seems to be collapsing around us!” she wrote back.
source.name: The New York Times
